column5: High volume of business commuters; expect short dwell times.
column8: How did you group the flights in your table?
column9: I grouped flights by intersecting Route Duration (Short-haul vs. Long-haul) with Departure Time (AM vs. PM), while keeping key regions like 'Europe' distinct.

column5: Standard mix of leisure and status passengers.
column8: Why did you choose that grouping method?
column9: This captures operational reality better than simple averages. Short-haul AM (business commuters) has very different lounge needs than Long-haul PM (leisure/sleepers).

column5: Standard mix of leisure and status passengers.
column8: What assumptions did you make about passenger eligibility?
column9: I calculated percentages directly from historical data. My analysis found that Europe (~21%) has higher eligibility than North America (~14%) due to frequent flyer density.

column5: Peak premium demand; passengers likely to dine in lounge.
column8: How can your model apply to future or changing flight schedules?
column9: The model uses dynamic logic (e.g., Time < 12 = AM) instead of hard-coded flight numbers, so it instantly adapts to any new schedule file.

column5: Standard mix of leisure and status passengers.
Standard mix of leisure and status passengers.
